awd_titl_txt: Snow: Museum Exhibit, Educational Outreach, and Learning Research
awd_abstract_narration:
With snow providing water for about 2 billion people worldwide and playing a major role in the Earth's climate through its high albedo and insulation properties, on-going alterations in global snow resources pose real and extremely expensive societal adaptation/mitigation problems.  The project goals are to (1) create opportunities for the public to learn about the vital role that snow plays in climate, water resources, and human lives, and (2) produce a better understanding of how culture affects informal Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics (STEM) learning.  The deliverables include: (a) an outreach program in Alaska that will visit 33 remote native villages, (b) a 2000 square foot museum exhibit on snow produced by the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry (OMSI) and exhibited at two additional museums during the life of the award, and (c) learning research, which will examine how the wide variation of cultural relationships to snow impacts learning during museum exhibits.  Each of these components will be evaluated over the course of the work.  The travelling exhibit is expected to be shown at three museums per year for eight years, with an anticipated cumulative audience of over one million.

The focus on snow will highlight a fascinating yet under-appreciated part of the Earth system. The project aims to educate the public about snow and to produce a more informed and thoughtful public in the face of potential expensive and difficult snow-related societal decisions.  Through informative displays, graphics, models, and other material, the project will engage traditionally under-served communities (at Native/remote villages) in Alaska, where a strong cultural connection to snow exists, as well as communities across the U.S. where the connection to snow can range from strong to weak.  Across this cultural gradient, the project will explore through oral interviews and surveys the public response to various types and designs of informal science learning (ISL) displays, attempting to isolate and control for the effect of cultural vs. individual response to the materials.  Informal learning theory specifies using front-end exploration of individual visitor-content relationships to guide exhibit design.  This project's research goal expands that approach to include the effects of cultural engagement with a topic to develop more general tools to guide and improve the design process.  The project is led by the University of Alaska Fairbanks in collaboration with OMSI (Oregon Museum of Science and Industry), and the Lifelong Learning Group at COSI (Center of Science and Industry), which leads the research, and the Goldstream Group, the evaluators. This project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants. The project has co-funding support from the Office of Polar Programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Oregon Museum of Science & Industry (OMSI) and the Geophysical Institute at the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) partnered on the collaborative project, Snow: Museum Exhibit, Educational Outreach, and Learning Research, funded by the National Science Foundation. OMSI's award (DRL-1808749) focused on the production of Snow: Tiny Crystals, Global Impact, a traveling exhibition for North American audiences. UAF's award (DRL-1810778) focused on outreach programs for Alaska Native villages and learning research. OMSI and UAF worked together on the traveling exhibition and other aspects of the collaborative project.

Snow: Museum Exhibit, Educational Outreach, and Learning Research explores the nature of snow and its vital role in global systems that sustain life on Earth. The project goals are to: 1) produce a better understanding of how culture affects informal STEM learning, while 2) providing informal learning opportunities that increase visitors' understanding of snow and its interrelationship with our global climate system and water supply. 

 OMSI collaborated with snow researchers and educators at UAF and Alaska Native advisors to create: 

  • A 2,000-square-foot traveling exhibition, titled Snow: Tiny Crystals, Global Impact
  • An exhibition website: https://omsi.edu/products/snow-tiny-crystals-global-impact 
  • An educator's guide to the exhibition for museum educators and classroom teachers

Snow: Tiny Crystals, Global Impact explores the nature and wonder of snow and the impact of climate change on our snowy planet. The exhibition follows snow's journey from tiny crystals to vast winter landscapes to abundant spring snowmelt. Visitors explore how snow shapes and sustains life on Earth, supplies water and cools our planet, and provides cultural and personal value. Visitors are invited to discover the weather conditions that shape snow crystals in an interactive snowstorm; compare the habitats found in tundra, taiga, and maritime snow; map the journey of Colorado River water from mountain snowpacks to desert cities and farms; and explore local impacts and community responses to climate change. 

 The exhibition was installed at OMSI in December 2021 and evaluated with museum visitors in spring 2022. Independent evaluation by the Goldstream Group found that the exhibition was highly engaging. Tracked and cued family groups were engaged, diligent, and thorough visitors and adult-child interactions were observed at all of the Snow exhibits. The evaluation report concluded:

 "Overall, Snow: Tiny Crystals, Global Impact was a successful exhibition. The strategies employed by the exhibition clearly contributed to visitor engagement, greater awareness of snow's properties and snow's role in human society and global climate, and to a lesser extent greater awareness of climate change and water supply as it relates to snow."

The full evaluation report will be posted here: https://omsi.edu/museum-services/evaluations

After its 4-month venue (December 2021 to April 2022) at OMSI, Snow traveled to the Fleet Science Center in San Diego for a 3-month summer venue. The national tour is expected to last eight years and reach over two million visitors at 20 additional venues.
